El cliente solicita un crédito para poder comprar medicamento por mayor y surtir su negocio con más medicamentos ya que tiene mucha demanda y así pueda obtener mejores ganancias y podrá tener una mejor estabilidad económica.
texts.en: This client lives in a relative's house with his life's companion. He has had a business selling medicine (a pharmacy) for several years in a shopping center close to his residence. He has a lot of customers because he is a friendly man when he is selling and his products are very high quality. The profits he earns cover his household expenses. The client is asking for a loan to be able to buy medications wholesale and stock his business with more medications since he has a lot of demand and this way he can have more financial stability.

loans.use: to buy medications wholesale.

loans.name: Rolando Obdulio

texts.es:
Rolando, solicita un nuevo préstamo porque necesita más capital de trabajo para seguir invirtiendo en su negocio; este le permitirá adquirir hierro de varias medidas, lamina, pintura,  entre otros materiales.
El crédito anterior le ayudo a realizar el trabajo de  ocho puertas que tenía pendientes terminar; las condiciones económicas y las circunstancias familiares han mejorado.
texts.en: Rolando is requesting a new loan because he needs more working capital to continue investing in his business.  This will let him acquire iron of various sizes, sheet metal, paint, and other materials.  His previous credit helped him complete a job of eight doors that he had to finish.  The economic condition and circumstances of his family have improved.

loans.use: to buy iron of various sizes, sheet metal, paint, and other materials.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: El cliente vive en casa propia con su esposa y su hijo, el tiene un negocio de carpintería desde hace varios años, hace puertas, ventanas, muebles, retratos y todo lo relacionado con la madera, tiene mucha clientela pues hace muy bien su trabajo, con las ganancias que obtiene logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, el cliente solicita un crédito para poder comprar materiales como: madera, pegamento, barniz, clavos, etc. para seguir con su negocio y asi poderle dar a su familia lo que necesita sin limitación alguna.
texts.en: The borrower lives in his own home with his wife and son.  He has had a carpentry business for several years.  He makes doors, windows, furniture, picture frames, and everything associated with wood.  He has a lot of customers because he does his job very well.  With the profits he earns, he covers his home's expenses.  He is requesting a loan to be able to buy materials like wood, glue, varnish, nails, etc., to continue with his business and in this way be able to give his family everything they need without limitations.

loans.use: to buy nails, wood, varnish, etc.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married and has two children. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past eight years she has operated a fruit- and vegetable-selling business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenges are high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the KES 25,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Raheli

texts.en:
Raheli is married to a husband who is a mason and has four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Raheli has operated a business selling fish for the past ten years, selling from home to her neighbors. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase bundles of fish for resale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish for resale.

loans.name: Ruqaia's Group

texts.en: Ruqaia is a 37 year-old woman. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan with her family. She is the mother of 5 children and belongs to a poor family. She has requested for a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan for her husband's shop--he runs a general store. WIth the loan amount, her husband will purchase corn oil, soyabean oil and olive oil to sell. This will help him to offer variety of cooking oils and to increase his net income to sustain his family. Ruqaia is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase corn oil, soyabean oil and olive oil to sell.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati is a married woman with children, all of whom attends school. She lives at her own house that has electricity but not piped water.

She has operated a food vending business for the past years, cooking chapati (flat bread) rice,dumplings and beans. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan of KES 30,000, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour for her food-vending business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour for her food-vending business

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
As a widowed mother of three children, Salvacion works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane and from pig-fattening. Salvacion is borrowing PHP 26,000 through NWTF to purchase bamboo, fishing nets, and other equipment for her fishing business.

Salvacion has been sustaining her business activities through her past 14 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to purchase bamboo, fishing nets, and other equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries and beverages that will expand his product inventory

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is forty-nine, married to Meshack, and the mother of seven children. She supplies tomatoes to her customers. She has been in the business for twenty-three years and she earns a monthly income of KES 50,000.

This will be Lucy's second loan with KADET LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to purchase five crates of tomatoes from farmers to sell to her customers.

She plans to use the profits to pay back the loan and reinvest in the business. In future she wants to be a successful business woman and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes for sale

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina is a 39-year-old lady from Shienwe in Kakamega County which is located in the western part of Kenya. She supports six people in her family and is married to Ainea, who is a farmer. She is blessed with three children who are 13, 11 and 5 years old.

Medina has a retail shop in her location and has been doing this business for the last three years. She comfortably makes a monthly income of 12,000 Kenyan shillings. She has applied for her first loan with KADET Ltd. which she will use to purchase shop items like sugar, salt, cooking oil and soft drinks for resale. She will plow the anticipated profit back into the business. Her dream is to educate her children and to own a supermarket.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, cooking oil, salt and soft drinks

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 50-year-old curio dealer in Nyali, Mombasa. He is a married father who supports five in his family, with the spouse providing for additional income. He has been in this business for the last 21 years and has done well.

This marks his third borrowing from KADET to finance his business. He will use the requested loan to purchase soap stones and gel for carving his curios, ornaments, and plastic thread for weaving. 

He will use the anticipated profit to expand his business. He hopes to have a bright future.

loans.use: to purchase soap stones and gel for carving his curios, ornaments, and plastic thread for weaving.

loans.name: Frederick

texts.en:
Frederick is a 57-year-old man who works as a teacher for the local government. A father to nine children, he is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He has been in this profession for 27 years after being inspired to the profession by the way teachers behaved back then.

Poor working conditions and a low salary are his challenges, while his dream is to educate his children up to the university level. Frederick intends to use the loan to pay school fees for his children and renovate his residential house.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children and renovate his residential house.

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en:
Fridah is a married woman with children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house without electricity or piped water.  She has operated a retail shop for the past four years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar.  She faces a major challenge of stiff competition from other retail operators. 

With the 30,000 KES loan that she is requesting, she wants to purchase sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
This is Narcisa. She previously accessed an 12,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP for her to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics to increase her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Narcisa hopes that her business will continue to expand and dreams of having a good future. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. There she also finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God as she studies.
 
*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Los Tulipanes (Flat) Group

texts.es:
Los Tulipanes es un grupo integrado por 6 personas alegres  y emprendedoras, esta ubicado en un municipio del estado de Veracruz, para poder llegar a la comunidad se toma un autobús que te deja en la carretera y después hay que caminar alrededor de 25 minutos para llegar a dicha comunidad. 

Doña Maribel  es uno delos integrantes de este grupo, platica que hace 5 años inicio con su negocio de venta de calzado por catalogo, la señora Maribel vende sus productos casa por casa en su comunidad y nos dice que gracias a Dios ya tiene algunas clientas pero que quiere que su negocio prospere y que para eso en algunas ocasiones se va a vender a otras comunidades. Maribel menciona que decidió iniciar su negocio porque desea que sus hijos tengan un mejor futuro y porque quiere apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de sus hijos y su hogar. 

La señora Maribel tiene la edad de 37 años, estudio hasta el sexto grado de primaria y esta casada con el señor Isaias con el cual tiene 4 hijos de los cuales dos son hombres a los que llama Isaias e Ismael y dos mujeres Yanely  y Yaretzi.

Ella realiza sus ventas de casa en casa en sus tiempos libres sale a ofrecer sus productos por medio de sus catálogos y levanta pedidos los cuales posteriormente surte y entrega.

Un crédito de VisionFund le ayudara a surtirse con variedad de zapatos.

Doña Maribel espera que su negocio siga creciendo, también nos dice que se encuentra agradecida con la fundación ya que con este prestamo su negocio prosperara y con sus ganacias espera continuar con la construccion de su casa.

Los demás inegrantes del grupo son:
Lorenza venta de ropa 
Jose Guadalupe venta de refrescos
Concepcion venta de refrescos
Juan Alberto venta de  pan 
Hermelinda venta de ropa
texts.en:
"Los Tulipanes" [The Tulips] is a group made up of six happy and enterprising people.  They are located in a city in the state of Veracruz.  To arrive to the community, one takes a bus that drops you off on the highway, and one then has to walk around 25 minutes to arrive to the community.

Doña Maribel is one of the members of the group.  She says that she started her business selling shoes by catalog five years ago.  She sells her products door to door in her community, and she tells us that, thanks to God, she already has some customers, but she wants her business to prosper, so sometimes she goes to other communities to sell.  Maribel mentions that she decided to start her business because she wants her children to have a better future and because she wants to help her husband with their children's and their home's expenses.

Maribel is 37.  She studied until the sixth grade.  She is married, and she has 4 children with Isaias.  Two are boys, Isaias and Ismael, and two are girls, Yanely and Yaretzi.

She does her sales door to door, and in her free time, she goes out to offer her products through catalogs and to take orders, which she later stocks and delivers. 

A credit from VisionFund will help her stock a variety of shoes.

Doña Maribel hopes that her business will keep growing.  She also tells us that she is thankful to the foundation since with this loan, her business will prosper.  With her profits, she hopes to continue with the construction of her home.

The other members of the group are:

Lorenza, who sells clothing
Jose Guadalupe, who sells soft drinks
Concepción, who sells soft drinks
Juan Alberto, who sells bread
Hermelinda, who sells clothing

loans.use: to buy a variety of shoes.

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
This is Maureen. The loan that she acquired helped a lot in her business for she was able to buy more products. The loan also helped in the education of her children as well as in their household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs.

Maureen would like to apply for another 20,000 Philippine peso loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help meet her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Maureen dreams to give her family a good life and future. She hopes that her business will continue to expand. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. This is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Priscillar

texts.en: This marks Priscillar's third loan to expand her poultry farm.  She has done well and has been able to repay her loans successfully.  She hopes to increase her farm and be able to supply both eggs and chicken meat to the entire Kilifi region of the coast.

loans.use: to purchase more dairy cattle feed, chicks, and chicken feed.

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en:
Samvel is still engaged in clothing. He has more than 16 years experience in this occupation.

He wants to take a loan from Kiva for the second time, as the first loan he has taken helped him very much to develop and enrich his business. In his business Samvel’s wife helps him very much. She also works in the local school as a teacher. 

As usual, all the needed clothes for selling Samvel brings from Yerevan wholesale markets, transporting them by rented car. During his long time in the trading business, Samvel has gained a lot of regular clients who prefer to buy women clothes from Samvel’s stall, as his merchandise is always renewed and more available for people who have low income. Thanks to his trading Samvel is able to meet his family needs and pay for his daughter’s training courses. 

Samvel needs a loan amount 900,000 Armenian drams to buy an assortment of new spring/summer women's clothes from Yerevan to resell in his stall in Vanadzor. Samvel hopes that this loan would have the same success as the last one did.

loans.use: To buy an assortment of new spring/summer women's clothes from Yerevan to resell

loans.name: Maria Reyna

texts.es: Doña María, tiene 54 años de edad, vive en unión libre con su pareja, reside en una aldea del municipio de Nueva Frontera, Santa Bárbara, junto a su conyugue y 3 hijos. Doña María se ha dedicado a la agricultura específicamente al cultivo de café. Hace 3 años que estableció su propio negocio de pulpería para vender productos comestibles como azúcar, granos básicos, churros, refrescos, dulces, productos de higiene y limpieza, verduras etc. ella a decidido solicitar un préstamo a ODEF por la cantidad de 15,000 Lempiras para surtir mas su negocio, comprara azúcar, jabón, refrescos, granos, verduras, churros y otros, con el objetivo de incrementar las ventas y los ingresos. Su plan es crecer poco a poco y llegar a ser la pulpería más grande de la comunidad.
texts.en: Doña María is 54 and lives her husband and 3 children in small town in Nueva Frontera, Santa Bárbara.  María has made a living through agriculture, specifically through growing coffee.  Three years ago, she established her own business of a small grocery store, selling consumables like sugar, basic grains, churros, soft drinks, sweets, hygiene and cleaning products, vegetables, etc.  She decided to request a loan from ODEF for 15,000 lempiras to stock her business more.  She will buy sugar, soap, soft drinks, grains, vegetables, churros, and other items, with the goal of increasing her sales and her income.  Her plan is to grow her business little by little and to be the biggest grocery store in the community.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, corn, sugar, soap, soft drinks, churros, and other items to stock her business.

loans.name: Loyda

texts.es:
La  señora Loyda  es una persona responsable, trabajadora y honesta,  vive  con sus hijas  y nietos en una comunidad de Choluteca en la zona sur de Honduras. 
Doña Loyda su negocio es  la   venta  de plástico desde hace más de 20 años. El préstamo lo necesita para la compra de  pailas, vasos, platos, baldes, etc.  Con el préstamo espera que las ventas en su negocio aumenten al tener más producto que ofrecer y atender mejor  a sus clientes.
Doña Loyda espera cubrir las necesidades  que tiene y mejorar un poco su calidad  de vida y la de su familia. En unos años espera que su negocio siga  creciendo  y se convierta en uno de  los  negocios más grande y reconocido de la zona.
Doña Loyda desea poder seguir apoyando que su familia ya  que  son de  escasos recurso  económicos 	




Choluteca, Honduras  –  Abril  del   2013
texts.en: Loyda is a responsible, hard-working, and honest person.  She lives with her daughters and grandchildren in a community in Choluteca in the southern part of Honduras.  Loyda has had a business selling plastic for more than 20 years.  She needs this loan to buy large dishes, cups, plates, buckets, etc.  She hopes that, with this loan, her sales will increase, she will have more products to offer, and she will be able to attend to her customers better.  Loyda hopes to cover the needs that she has and to improve her and her family's quality of life a little.  In years to come, she hopes that her business will keep growing and that it will become one of the largest and best-known businesses in the area.  Loyda hopes to be able to continue supporting her family since they have scarce resources.

loans.use: to buy large dishes, cups, plates, buckets, etc., for her business.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is a 33-year-old married man who has five children. They live in Sana'a, Yemen. He is a doctor and earns a small salary which is not enough to cover all the family's needs.

Mohammed had an accident which dis-enabled him to continue his career for a period. He believes that nobody will lend you money if you stay at home, so he is forced to continue his work in order to provide for his family. He is requesting a 175,000 Yemeni rial loan from AMB to help cover the cost of purchasing new living room furniture in order to improve the living conditions in his house. Taking out this loan will allow him and his family to have comfortable furniture so they can enjoy living in their house.

loans.use: to cover the cost of purchasing new living room furniture in order to improve the living conditions in his house.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en: As a married mother of 7 children, Salvacion works hard to support her family.  She has a fish vending business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from selling clothes.  Salvacion is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to her customers.  Salvacion has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF.  She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Becham Group

texts.en:
Christian is a married man in his late 30’s with a daughter who is attending school.  Since 2000, he has been managing his life by running a poultry business.  He is doing fine in this project with the ability to collect more eggs per day.  He works from 6am to 6pm daily and is able to earn a better return each month. 

This will be his 4th loan request from Tujijenge, Tanzania.  With the previous loans, all of which were successfully repaid, he managed to buy more chicken feed.  This enabled his chickens to lay more eggs.  With the interest earned, he bought a farm, paid school fees, and covered his household expenses.  He will use this loan to buy chicks and chicken feed.  He dreams to buy more chicks and own a big farm.

He will share this loan with his loan group, Becham, which totals 10 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
This is Perla. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy all the needed products for her variety store. The loan also helped in their household expenditures and in the education of her child. She has been in this business for five years now. She is working hard to provide for their everyday expenses.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and child’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Perla's dream is for her business to continuously grow, and she hopes to have their own house. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is 57 years old, married, and blessed with 6 children.  She owns and manages a retail store in their village for almost 4 years.  She would like to obtain a loan in the amount of 35,000 PHP to purchase canned goods, shampoo, soaps, breads, coffee, and beverages to sell.  In this business, she earns a net income of 500 PHP daily.  She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she can utilize it immediately in her store.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, shampoo, soaps, breads, coffee, and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 48 years old and married with five children.  She works hard to provide for her family by running a general store in the Philippines.  Teresita requested a 17,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more items like shampoo, toothpaste, canned goods, diapers, and other miscellaneous items.

Teresita has borrowed and repaid ten loans from NWTF before this loan.  She has been running the general store for four years and also earns income from food vending.  Teresita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items like shampoo, toothpaste, canned goods, diapers and other miscellaneous items.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
This is Mary Jane.  She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to pay for spare parts, accessories, and maintenance of their jeepney unit.  Her earnings were a big help in their personal household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan for spare parts and for maintenance of their jeepney unit.  Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs.  She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mary Jane hopes that her business will continue to grow and she dreams of having a better living.  She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.  Here she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

-Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins.  They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines against the invading Japanese.  Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain.  Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital, and to pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman with three children, all of whom go to school.  She owns a house that is without electricity and piped water.  She has operated a charcoal-selling business for the past five years, selling  to her neighbors from home.  A major challenge that she faces is the seasonality of her business. 

With the requested loan, she wants to purchase more charcoal to resell.  She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Khalid

texts.en:
Khalid is a 47-year-old man who lives with his family in Lahore, Pakistan.  He is an old, poor person who cannot do much work due to back pain.  He is the only earning person in the family and his family depends on his income.

Since 2007, he has been operating a highly productive shoe business in the main market of the area.  Presently, he is interested in purchasing a variety of shoes to offer more choices to his customers.  This will help him to earn more income which will help to sustain his family life.  He hopes that the loan will be effective for his business.  He is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of shoes to sell.

loans.name: Kinepna Group

texts.en: “Kinepna” literally means "Hope" and these nine hardworking women named themselves Kinepna Group. Kimneichong is pictured with her hand raised and she is the featured borrower member. She says her participation in the Kinepna Group makes her stronger socially and financially. She also says hope is the driving factor to be successful in life. She is single and lives with her mother, brother and her sister-in-law. Kimneichong runs a tea shop-cum-variety shop in the village where she lives. Her shop is located near her house. She sells a few essential commodities including candles, kerosene, salt, sugar, cereals, matchsticks, cigarettes (exported and local), betel nuts, betel leaves, shampoo sachets, etc. Her tea shop is busy – especially in the mornings when village elders throng in for chit-chat and to enjoy tea. She also prepares toast and puri in the morning. She wanted to help her brother and sister-in-law with the farm but opted for opening a tea shop and running a variety shop instead because her mother is old now. She manages the household chores and also takes care of her aged mother, so she is better off running the shop because she can stay close to her mother. She gets supplies from the city and sells them in the village at a little higher rate to make a profit. She also supports the family in household financial maintenance. Her inception in the group enabled her to join a local investment group where one deposits a monthly saving and the amount can be withdrawn after the completion of a year. Her savings so far are small and she hopes to make larger savings once she can expand her shop by refilling with more stock. With this Kiva loan, she will purchase detergent soaps, detergent powder, rice and edible oils. Her future plan is to be able to run the shop without needing a loan, and she says she will work hard to achieve her plan. She thanks Kiva and WSDS for the support and enabling her to look forward to her plans. She says, "Thank you, Kiva."

loans.use: to purchase stock for her tea shop and variety shop and make a better income.

loans.name: Mustarfa

texts.en:
Mustarfa is a 51-year-old married man living in Bundibugyo, Uganda, with eight children. He has been in cocoa farming since 1996. He also gets a side income from cocoa products, which he buys from others and sells to the factory. 

Unpredictable weather changes and price fluctuations affect his business growth, while his desire is to become the leading cocoa producer in the area. Mustarfa intends to use the loan to prune his garden and buy cocoa to sell.

loans.use: to prune his garden and buy cocoa to sell.

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael is 54 years old and from Nakuru. He is married to Eunice. They have four children.

He has a business of selling tires, which he has operated for the past seven years. He has applied for his third loan from KADET LTD. to enable him to buy more stock of tires. He repaid his previous loan on time and hopes to expand his business and pay school fees with the anticipated profit.

He hopes to open other branches of the same business in the near future.

loans.use: To buy stock of tires.

loans.name: Best Ladies Group

texts.en:
Pictured are the members of Best Ladies Group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The featured leader of this group is Kadiatu. Kadiatu is 28 years old; she was born in Kono city, in eastern Sierra Leone but is currently residing in Waterloo, together with her husband and children. For many years now, Kadiatu has been selling cooked rice with delicious sauce. With this loan, she will buy cooking ingredients, such as rice, palm oil, tomatoes, onions and salt in bulk to avoid buying these items at retail prices.

loans.use: buy cooking ingredients, such as rice, palm oil, tomatoes, onions and salt in bulk

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en:
This is Carolyn. The loan that she acquired helped her not just in her business but also in the education of her children as well as in her household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday expenses.

She would like to apply for a new 27,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Carolyn dreams that her children will finish their studies and hopes for the continuous success of her business. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy land for dairy farming.

loans.name: Habib-Ur- Rehman

texts.en: Habib-ur-Rehman is a 33-year-old man. He lives in Lahore, Pakistan, with his family. Since 2008, he has been running a cloth selling business in the main market. The new season has started; therefore, he is interested in purchasing a variety of new cloth for his shop. However, due to lack of finances, he finds it difficult. Therefore, he has requested a loan amount of 100,000 PKR (Pakistan rupees) from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase ladies cloth, a variety of gents' shirts and trouser cloth. He is hopeful that the loan will help him to offer a variety of new clothes of the summer season to the customers and to increase his net income and savings. He is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of unstitched cloth to sell.

loans.name: Sabenty Traders 1 Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Sabenty Traders I” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more profit and consequently, improve on their standards of living. 

The featured leader of this group is Aminata. Aminata is age 39; she was born in Masampa village, but she is currently residing in Waterloo, together with her husband and six children. Her husband is a driver, and two of her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For many years now, Aminata has been selling charcoal, foo-foo (food made out of cassava roots), palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), etc.  With the help of this loan, Aminata will buy the aforementioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy charcoal, foo-foo (food made out of cassava roots), palm oil, etc., in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a trisikad transport business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 26,000 through NWTF to buy spare parts for her trisikad transport business.

Janeth has been in this business for five years. Janeth earns extra income from selling clothing.

Janeth has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her trisikad.

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
This is Ariel. He previously accessed an 11,000 PHP loan that he used to buy spare parts and accessories and to maintain his tricycle unit. His earnings were a big help with his personal, household and business expenditures.

He would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan for him to buy spare parts and to maintain his tricycle unit. The profits from his business will definitely help him sustain his daily needs. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Ariel dreams of having another tricycle and hopes to find a partner in life. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and to maintain his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is a married woman with six children. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Constance operates a food making business, making staples like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbors. With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Enkhbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Enkhbaatar, 42 years old, lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in their own house on a plot of land. He has been rendering transportation services to local people using his own truck for seven years. Usually, he transports goods such as coal, firewood and building materials. His wife has been selling clothes at a trade center for a long time. His two children both go to high school. 

Using his previous loan, he purchased building materials and completed his house construction work. Two years passed, and the house they live in was deteriorated due to the Mongolian harsh weather such as a strong storm, dust and frosts. He is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT (Mongolian tugriks) to repair the house's interior components, such as walls, ceilings and floors. As a result, they can live in a comfortable and warm place. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to repair the house's interior components.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a 55-year-old mixed farmer. He is married to Margaret, who is also a farmer. He has been practicing mixed farming for the past 10 years with a monthly income of 9,000 KES (Kenyan shillings), which he uses to support his family. Francis is applying for his third loan term from KADET LTD. after repaying the previous loans successfully.  

He is glad and appreciates the financial support he has received from KADET and Kiva. His farm is doing well. He will use the loan to purchase a bigger plot of land to expand his farming. 

He will plow the anticipated profits from his farm back into the business.  His hopes and dreams are to purchase a piece of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: to purchase a bigger plot of land.

loans.name: No Weapon Group

texts.en:
Enitor is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Enitor was born in Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city, 32 years ago. She is single with three children who are attending primary and secondary schools. 

For many years now, Enitor has been selling soft drinks, beers, bottled water, biscuits, sweets, etc. With the help of this loan, Enitor and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently, improve their living conditions. 

Enitor will use her share of the loan (1,000,000 Sierra Leone leones) to expand her business; she will buy soft drinks, beers, bottled water, biscuits, sweets, etc., at wholesale rates to add to her current ones.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, beers, bottled water, biscuits, sweets, etc., at wholesale rates to add to her current ones.

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en:
This is Ivy. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy the needed spare parts for her tricycle. The loan also helped with her household expenditures. She has had this business for five years. She and her husband are working to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for a new 23,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan to buy spare parts and pay for the maintenance of her tricycle unit. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Ivy hopes that her business will last longer and dreams to have a bright future. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work. It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and the maintenance of her tricycle unit.

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en:
Saleh is 43 years old. He is a married man and has four children who live in Sana`a, Yemen. He is the breadwinner of his family. 

He is a teacher getting a low salary, who tries to work hard every day to be able to offer the best to his family. He feels embarrassed when guests come to visit and he does not have furniture for his home. He is requesting the loan in order to purchase furniture for his house.

His dream is to keep on acquiring the things he lacks. The challenge he faces is fighting any problems that arise.

loans.use: to purchase furniture for his house.

loans.name: Break Through Group

texts.en:
Six,who is in her late 30s, is married with four children of whom three are in school. The remaining one is a grownup. For three years now, Six has been running a mamalishe business (a restaurant). She is doing fine in this project. She works from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair return per month.

This will be her second loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy washing basins and saucepans to replace the old ones. With the profit earned, she covered home expenses. She will use this loan to start selling charcoal. She dreams to own a hotel.

She will share this loan with her loan group, BREAK THROUGH, which totals 14 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to start selling charcoal.

loans.name: Senzeni

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 28-year-old Senzeni from Bulawayo. She is single with two children. Senzeni runs a clothing business. The business has been in operation for five years. She says the main challenge she faces is the competition from bigger retailers who offer longer credit facilities. 

Senzeni has requested a loan of $500 to replenish stock for the coming winter season. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to help with the payment of school fees and other household expenses. In the future, Senzeni plans to open a clothing boutique.

loans.use: to replenish stock for the coming winter season.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She is staying together with her husband, who is watchman. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past four years, she has operated a firewood selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to be a wholesale supplier of firewood in the village. 

With the 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Luigj

texts.en:
Luigj is applying for another loan, a larger one this time to build a stable for his animals. 

With his previous loan, he was able to buy chickens. "This business has been going very well. My son and my wife have been the ones who really put efforts at it, while I was striving to have something going on with my little construction activity," Luigj said. 

"I wanted to thank all the Kiva lenders who gave me and my family the opportunity to start up a business, and this is not little for us. :) Thanks again to everyone," Luigj ended.

loans.use: to build a stable for the animals.

loans.name: Teimuraz

texts.en:
Teimuraz is 34 years old. He lives in Kutaisi District with his wife and parents. Teimuraz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the monthly salary earned by Teimuraz’s father, who is working as an builder at a private building company. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Teimuraz requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Teimuraz has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Teimuraz will start sunflower production. He will purchase all the needed equipment and raw materials and will start packing bags. He will sell the produced sunflowers at local markets at a good price. This will increase the income of his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to produce sunflowers.

loans.name: Black Stone Group

texts.en:
Mohamed is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Mohamed was born in Waterloo 47 years ago. He is married to a trader, and the couple has two children who are attending primary and secondary schools, respectively. Mohamed sells cigarettes, sugar, batteries, milk, etc., and has been doing this business for 15 years now.

With the help of this loan, Mohamed and his group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently, improve their living conditions. 

Mohamed will use his share of the loan (500,000 Sierra Leone leones) to buy the aforementioned items in bulk to add to his current stock.

loans.use: to buy cigarettes, sugar, batteries, milk, etc., in bulk to add to his current stock.

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
This marks Salim's second borrowing to purchase bales of baking flour and cooking oil for his bakery business, which has since expanded. 

His sales per day have increased greatly, and he has been able to service his previous loan successfully. He hopes to dominate his area of supply as the best baker with the most reasonable prices for baked items.

loans.use: to purchase baking flour and cooking oil for his bakery business.

loans.name: Apple Group

texts.en:
Jane, who is in her early 50s, is married with five children who are grown-ups. She has been running a catering business since 2002. She works from 8 a.m. to midnight daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Jane's 16th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to start a decoration business. So, for the previous years, she has been increasing the stock of materials. She keeps on buying materials according to the color of the year. She bought more food for the catering business and has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to build her house, pay school fees and cover household expenses. She will use this loan to buy up-to-date materials and new server dishes. Her dream is to one day be able to build another house.

Jane will share this loan with her loan group, "Apple," which has 11 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy up-to-date materials and new serving dishes.

loans.name: Sabenty Trader 55 Group

texts.en:
Isatu is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Isatu was born in Kalmaro village, 36 years ago. She is married to a trader, and the couple has two children who are attending primary and secondary school. Isatu sells palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, etc., and has been doing this business for six years now.

With the help of this loan, Isatu and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Isatu will use her share of the loan (500,000 Sierra Leon leones) to buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, etc., in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, margi seasoning, salt, pepper, etc., in bulk to add to current stock.

loans.name: Benedict

texts.en:
Benedict is still running his businesses which are doing very well. He now earns a monthly income of KES. 25,000 which he uses to support his family.
He is applying for a third business loan. He intends to use the loan to purchase a motorcycle to start a motorcycle transport business.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Felton

texts.en:
This marks Felton's second loan to purchase a cow at a cheaper price to slaughter, as floods are affecting parts of the country and rendering the animals with no place to graze. 

He hopes to graze the animals for his butchery business and gain greater proceeds from their sale in the near future.

loans.use: to buy a cow for slaughter.

loans.name: Laini

texts.en:
Laini is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water.

Laini has operated a business selling spare parts for the past six years, selling from home to her neighbors. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase more spare parts for resale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more spare parts for resale.

loans.name: Munkhtsetseg

texts.en: Mrs. Munkhtsetseg is 50 years old and lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in a rented apartment. She has been selling office supplies as well as hats, widget and shoes for thirteen years and has accumulated a vast amount of experience in the sales business. Her son will graduate from high school this year and will enroll in university. She is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to purchase goods such as hats, shoes, books and pens in large quanties. As a result, she can continue to run her business without worrying about inventory shortage. Also she is contributing to the community by providing jobs by hiring two sales people at her stall. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase goods such as hats, shoes, pens and books for her market stall.

loans.name: Shazia Group

texts.en:
Shazia is a 47-year-old woman living in Rawalpindi, Pakistan with her spouse and five children. Since 2009, her husband has been running a small vegetable shop. This is the only source of income for their family. Due to an increase in the demand from the customers, Shazia has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan. She is the member of a 3 person group and will use the loan for the expansion of her husband's shop. With the loan investment, her husband will buy a variety of fresh vegetables that will allow him to offer more varieties to his clients and increase his sales and income. He would also build one more room to add some more space to his shop. Her husband is a very hardworking and honest man and is confident about his family’s bright future.
NOTE: In the picture Shazia is raising her hand

loans.use: to purchase variety of fresh vegetables.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine lives in the Nkubu area of Kenya, which hosts a campus of Mt. Kenya University. She has 6 children and has been supporting them for 14 years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, crops, transportation services, and a personal farming. The photo was taken from her residential house and not from the farm.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming is selling milk. Her biggest challenge is crop failure and poor prices for farm produce. Animals on her farm have been given the name of Kageni. Josephine is requesting a loan to construct a zero grazing unit.

Josephine chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they are the best financier for farmers. Josephine learned about the importance of savings during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session.

Her highest monthly expense is school fees, and the increase in sales from this loan will allow her to pay the school fees.
As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Josephine owns a cow, pig, poultry, and a motorcycle but does not own a pump, bicycle, or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, electricity, running water, TV, and DVD but does not have solar power or a sewing machine.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to construct a zero grazing unit.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Gracious Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 48-year-old Simbiso from Masvingo. She is married with four children and two of them attend school. Simbiso runs a clothing business which sells shoes, skirts, blouses and socks. The business has been operating for 6 years. She says the main challenge being faced is of her debtors failing to pay on time. Simbiso has requested a loan of $1200 to buy tracksuits, jackets, belts and jerseys for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will enable her to improve the welfare of her family. In the future Simbiso plans to own a boutique shop in the city center.

loans.use: to buy tracksuits, jackets, belts and jerseys.

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah is 26 years old from Tulkarem.
He has owned a farm since 2010, in which he plants different kinds of vegetables and fruits in greenhouses.
He asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy more fruit and vegetable seeds to plant and to build a new greenhouse. This will help his productivity increase as well as his income which will help him improve his financial situation and help achieve his dream of owning a big farm.

loans.use: to buy more fruit and vegetable seeds to plant and to build a new greenhouse

loans.name: Artush

texts.en:
Artush is 40 years old. After graduating high school he has worked in the Ararat regional forest reserve as a forester. Artush is married and lives with his wife, two children and retired parents in Vedi city which is in the Ararat region.
Artush is also engaged in farming and animal breeding. He raises vegetables on his own plot of land near his house which he sells at the Vedi vegetable markets. Artush has a large barn for animals where he breeds two cows and piglets. Artush is the only breadwinner in his large family. His family members help him with the farming and he couldn't overcome some of the difficulties in agriculture without their support.
As Artush said it is very important to provide his animals with the best conditions. The barn must be comfortable for breeding and warm for winter months.
Artush is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to repair the roof of his animal’s barn and to buy fodder for them. It is the first loan with Kiva and Artush thanks the lenders for their support.

loans.use: to repair the roof of  the barn and to buy fodder for his animals.

loans.name: Zahide

texts.en:
Zahide is 31 years old and married with three children. She is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with her husband and daughters in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. When she was 13, she started to learn to work in agriculture. Her parents were the ones who taught her to grow fruits and vegetables, since it was their only source of income. She has been growing vegetables and fruits for more than 8 years now. She sells her crops in the central bazaar to make profits in order to support her family.
Zahide’s income from her business is 350 AZN. In order to increase the living conditions of her family, she plans to expand her business. This requires a lot of dedication and effort. She believes in the near future her son will help her to expand the business. Since the vegetable and fruits business is profitable and a fun business, she wants the business to continue and prosper.
Zahide needs a 1800 AZN loan to buy fertilizers, seeds and fruit trees. Her biggest wish is to offer her children an education so that they can have good careers and help their family. This is her third loan and she has a good loan history.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds and fruit trees.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
This is Ruth, who is 48 years old and a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Jessie, a welder and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ruth operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan to help her continue the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Ruth hopes that her business will grow even more and dreams that her family will always stick together. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week. She can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Asaf

texts.en:
Asaf is 42 years old with 2 sons. He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his wife and sons in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. From past 18 years he has been raising sheep because mutton is in high demand in this region. Asaf is a retired person with an income of 330 AZN monthly from this business. This is a very profitable business and Asaf is doing it together with his wife.
Asaf is keeping a flock of sheep in his own yard. He fattens them and takes their meat to the central bazaar, where butchers and customers purchase from him. People use mutton for traditional dishes like kababs, dolmas, pilovs, etc.
He has taken loan from Aqroinvest before and has a good loan history. This is going to be his 2nd loan. This time he requires 1600 AZN in order to purchase 12 sheep in order to sell more meat in summer. He is optimistic about this loan, because in summer more people consume meat, due to the holidays and increased customers in restaurants.

loans.use: to purchase 12 sheep in order to sell more meat in summer.

loans.name: Rafeela Group

texts.en:
Rafeela is a 24-year-old responsible mother of two children. She is living in Rawalpindi, Pakistan along her husband and children in a rented house. Her husband has run a garment shop for five years and this is the only source of income for her family. Her household expenses are very large compared to the business income, because she is facing a lot of financial problems in life.
As a member of a two person group, Rafeela has requested a loan from Kiva’s partner BRAC Pakistan. With the loan amount her husband would buy new varieties of dresses, shirts, jeans, and suits to attract more customers. His sales would increase and his monthly income and savings would also be increased. With the profit amount Rafeela would purchase her own house.
She is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan for helping her. NOTE: In the picture Rafeela is raising her hand.

loans.use: to purchase dresses and clothes for the garment shop.

loans.name: Mouhammad

texts.en:
Mouhammad is from Iraq, he is 32 years old and lives with his brothers. Mouhammad and 2 of his brothers provide the income for his parents.
Mouhammad is a grocer and has been doing this since 2010. Mouhamamd offers various products for his clients like smokes, milk products and detergents. He has gained good experience and has been gradually growing with fame and respect in the area.
Mouhammad is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD. He will use this loan to install a display window. Mouhammad aims to grow his business and increase his profits so that he may take a better care of his parents.

loans.use: to install a display window.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with three children and all of them attend school. She is not looking after any additional family members.
She has been operating a pub for five years, working a full week. She also operates an eating-place for additional income.
She has requested for a loan of UGX 2,000,000 from MCDT- SACCO to enable her to stock more crates of beer, soda, spirits and local brew. Her challenges include recovering money from clients who buy on credit and also seasonality. Her dream is to expand her business to a bigger pub, thus creating more employment and also to build her own house. She joined MCDT because she did not have to give collateral in order to access loans. She rents a house with access to electricity and no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, soda, spirits and local brew.

loans.name: Vènan André

texts.fr: Vènan André est âgé de 52 ans et est marié à Antoinette. Le couple a sept enfants dont certains scolarisés. Vènan André vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la famille. Vènan André n’a pas fréquenté l'école, mais a appris la couture. Vènan André exerce ce métier depuis trente ans ; ce qui lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. En vue de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Vènan André sollicite pour la quatrième fois, l'appui financier de ALIDé. Les crédits précédemment obtenus ont tous été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Vènan André is 52 years old and married to Antoinette.  The couple has seven children, some of whom go to school.  Vènan André lives with his wife and children and covers the family's various expenses with his wife.

Vènan André did not go to school.  Instead, he learned to sew.  He has been working as a tailor for the past 30 years, an activity which allows him to meet the needs of his family.  In order to meet the demand from his customers, he is requesting financial support from ALIDé for the fourth time.  His previous loans were all duly repaid.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and sewing supplies.

loans.name: Khurelpurev

texts.en:
Mr. Khurelpurev, 24 years-old, lives with his mother, wife and son in Ulaanbaatar the capital city of Mongolia. He has been working as a waiter at a pub since 2010 and during his free time, he provides a taxi service to local people.

His mother has a position of a senior professional at a health center and his wife is currently staying at home looking after their baby. Recently his old automobile, which had been repaired earlier using his previous loan, stopped working completely so he is requesting a loan of 2000000 MNT in order to purchase an electric car. Electric cars contribute to cleaner air in cities because they produce no harmful pollution at the tailpipe from the onboard source of power, such as particulates (soot), volatile organic compounds, hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, ozone, lead, and various oxides of nitrogen. From personal views, purchasing of this type of car should be encouraged everywhere because Ulaanbaatar has the worst air pollution in the world. 

The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase an electric car.

loans.name: Asif

texts.en:
Asif is 35 years-old. He is the father of two daughters.  He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his wife and daughters in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. 

He has been raising seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last 12 years. He chose this business because it is profitable and because there is always a high demand for fresh crops. People use fresh vegetables every day and include them in many national dishes, such as pilau and dolma. Fresh fruits are served at every family table in Azerbaijan and are often made into fresh punch. 

Asif  sells his crops at the BIlasuvar central bazaar. His monthly income is 100 AZN. His wife actively helps him to raise his crops. Asif  also receives a pension.

As his products are in high demand, Asif wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables in order to satisfy market demand. For this purpose, he has applied for a loan in the amount of 1700 AZN. He will buy seeds and fertilizers with his loan funds. This will be his third  loan and he has a positive loan history.

loans.use: to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to cover market demand.

loans.name: Viasity Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone is very pleased to present to you members of the “Viasity group’’. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to request a loan of SLL 500,000.00 for each in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Ada is the featured leader of this group. Ada is 41-years-old and married with three children – one in primary school and two in secondary school. She sells cigarettes, soap, tooth-pastes, batteries, etc. and has been doing this business for eight years now. With the help of this loan, she will invest in her business by buying the above items in large quantities to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy cigarettes, soap, tooth-pastes, batteries, etc. in large quantities to add to her current stock.

loans.name: La Gloria Group

texts.es:
La Gloria es el nombre de un grupo integrado por 8 personas, este grupo se encuentra ubicado en una comunidad que está rodeada por sembradíos de caña de azúcar. Además, muy cerca se encuera un río muy bonito que en verano es visitado por personas de diferentes comunidades. 

Doña Rosa es uno de los integrantes de dicho grupo, ella se ha dedicado a la elaboración de dulces típicos de su región(cocadas, jamoncillos y dulces de leche) por mas de 30 años, y dice que en sus inicios fue muy difícil ya que no sabia como elaborarlos pero tenia la intención de trabajar para salir adelante con su hijo ya que era madre soltera, así que pidió a  su hermana que le ensañara a realizar los dulces, aprendió muy rápido  y poco a poco fue haciendo buenos clientes, Doña Rosa realiza sus ventas fuera de su comunidad en lugares cercanos, ademas comenta que se siente muy contenta con su actividad ya que ha sido tradición familiar ya que la primera en elaborar estos dulces fue su abuela y ha pasado este oficio por dos generaciones.
Un préstamo de VisionFund le ayudará a comprar cocos, azúcar, ajonjolí, leche y colorantes para la elaboración de sus dulces.

Doña Rosa también realiza pequeñas ventas de ropa para obtener un ingreso extra y espera con sus ganancias hacer algunas remodelaciones a su hogar y si quedara un poco iniciar un ahorro para lo que se presente.

Los demás integrantes del grupo son:
 
Teodora venta de ropa 
Rolando venta de refrescos
Zuleima venta de calzado 
Ana Luisa venta de cosmeticos
Irma venta de comida 
Angelica venta de dulces
Odalis venta de ropa
texts.en:
This eight-member group is called "La Gloria" and is based in a community surrounded by sugar cane fields.  Nearby there there is also a very pretty river which is visited by people various different areas.

Rosa is one member of  "La Gloria".  For thirty years she has made a living producing typical sweet products from the region (such as "cocadas", coconut sweets, "jamoncillos", fudge, and "dulce de leche").  Rosa tells us that in the beginning the work was difficult as she did not know how to make the sweets. However, a single mother, she wanted to work in order that she and her son could prosper so she asked her sister to teach her how to make the sweets.  Rosa learned very quickly and, little by little, she gained good customers.  Rosa goes out to sell in nearby communities and tells us she is very happy with her work as it is a family tradition.  The first person in her family to start making sweets was her grandmother and the skills have now been passed on to two generations.

A Vision Fund loan will help Rosa to buy coconuts, sugar, sesame seeds, milk and colouring for making her sweets.

Rosa also makes a few sales of clothes in order to have an extra income.  She hopes that, with her profits, she will be able to do some renovations to her home and any leftover money she will save for a rainy day.

The other members of the group:

Teodora - sells clothes
Rolando - sells drinks
Zuleima - sells footwear
Ana Luisa - sells make-up
Irma - sells food
Angelica - sells sweets
Odalis - sells clothes.

loans.use: to make and sell typical sweets products.

loans.name: Reyes Elias

texts.es: Don reyes vive junto a su compañero de vida y sus 2 hijos; el se dedica a la agricultura específicamente al cultivo de maíz y frijol, tiene muchos años de trabajar en este rubro y se ha hecho de experiencia muy valiosa que le permite obtener las mejores cosechas , el terreno de cultivo está ubicado en una zona de incidencia agrícola, el comercia en todas las zonas aledañas y ya tiene mucha clientela fija, estas personas siempre prefieren su producto pues es de calidad y a precios realmente accesibles además el servicio es inigualable. Reyes es una hombre  dedicado a su labor,  quiere aprovechar el auge de su negocio para aumentar la producción y así poder tener mejores ganancias, necesita invertir en insumos pero necesita de capital por eso solicita un crédito que le permita comprar semilla de maíz, frijol, abono, insecticida, herramienta, etc. para obtener mejores cosechas y  a la vez tiene la confianza que podrá darle a su familia la vida que se merecen.
texts.en: Reyes lives with his partner and two children.  He makes a living in agriculture growing corn and beans.  He has many years experience in this work and his experience is very valuable as it allows him to get better harvests.  The land Reyes cultivates is in an area where there is a lot of agricultural work.  Reyes goes out to the neighbouring areas to sell his products and he now has a strong customer base.  Customers always prefer Reyes' products as they are of good quality and sold at accessible prices; you also can't beat the customer service.  Reyes is dedicated to his work and wants to take advantage of the boom in his business to increase production and thus earn higher profits.  To do this, he needs to invest in supplies but requires capital and so is applying for a loan that will allow him to buy corn, beans, manure, insecticide, tools and more.  This will give him better harvests and, at the same time, Reyes is confident that, with this investment, he will be able to give his family what they deserve.

loans.use: to buy manure, fertilisers, seeds and more.

loans.name: Angela Del Carmen

texts.es:
Doña Ángela habita   en la ciudad de Estelí ella tiene una pulpería la cual empezó con mucho sacrificio ella comenzó con un poco de dinero que tenía ahorrado y otro poco que le dio su esposo compró arroz y azúcar eso fueron los primeros productos luego la gente le iba comprando más y entonces fue creciendo su negocio en pulpería ha sido su primer negocio pero ya tenía experiencia en ventas ya que se dedicaba a la venta de cosméticos doña Ángela necesita este crédito por que sus clientes han aumentado y va a comprar arroz ,azúcar, aceite ,frijoles ,harina, maíz, gaseosas papel higiénico y otros productos.  
Sus planes futuro son ampliar su negocio y que sea la venta más grande del barrio donde haya de todo un poco  sus planes futuros son hacer los cuartos de su casa para que sus únicos dos hijos tengan  un techo digno donde vivir, sus hijos cuando ellos no están en la escuela la apoyan en la venta ella cree que este crédito le va ayudar ya que va surtir y saldrá adelante con sus clientes sus únicos ingresos son lo que hace en el negocio y la ayuda de su esposo.
texts.en:
Ángela lives in the city of Estelí and has a small grocery store.  She started it with a lot of sacrifice and a little money that she had saved and a little more that her husband gave her.  With this money, Ángela bought rice and sugar and these were the first products that she sold.  Later on people started buying more and her business began to grow.  This was Ángela's first business but she had previous experience in sales as before she made a living selling make-up.  Ángela needs this loan because her number of customers has increased and she is going to buy rice, sugar, oil, beans, flour, corn, fizzy drinks, toilet paper and other products.

Ángela's future plan is to expand the business and to have the highest sales in the barrio, where there are all sorts of shops.  Ángela also wants to make rooms in her house so that her only two children can have a decent place to live.  When they are not at school, her children help their mother with sales.  Ángela thinks that this loan will help her to stock-up and to prosper with her customers.  Ángela's only income comes from the business and from her husband.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, beans, flour, corn, fizzy drinks, toilet paper and other products.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: La clienta  vive junto a su esposo y su  hijos de 4 años de edad en casa propia, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa, tiene varios años con el negocio y eso le ha regalado mucha experiencia que le permite obtener las mejores ganancias, el negocio está ubicado en su lugar de residencia, se ha hecho de mucha clientela pues las personas saben que todo es de calidad, a precios accesibles y con un servicio inigualable siempre a la orden y al gusto de los clientes; ella es una mujer emprendedora, dedicada a su labor y muy luchadora día con día se esfuerza al máximo para ganarse una vida mejor y un gran éxito para el futuro, en las últimas semanas aumento la demanda y quiere aprovechar para una nueva inversión, pero no posee de suficiente capital que la respalde por eso  solicita un crédito que le permita comprar ropa: camisas, faldas, ropa para  niños, blusas, etc. y asi surtir su negocio para obtener mejores ganancias y tener la esperanza que llevara a su hogar seguridad económica.
texts.en: This client lives with her husband and her 4 year old kids in their own house. She works selling clothes and has been running this business for some years and this has given her the experience to make a better income. The business is located in her place of residence. She has many customers as people know that all her goods are high quality at affordable prices and that she offers unequaled service - always meeting the orders and tastes of her customers. She is a very enterprising woman who is very dedicated to her work and she strives hard. Day in and day out, she works herself to the maximum to achieve a better life and great success for the future. Demand for her products has increased in recent weeks and she wants to take advantage by buying more stock, but she doesn't have enough capital to make this possible. So, she is requesting a loan to buy more clothing: shirts, skirts, children's clothes, blouses, etc, and in this way to supply her store in order to make the best profits and to have the hope that she can bring her household greater economic security.

loans.use: to buy clothing in bulk: skirts, blouses, children's clothes, etc.

loans.name: Arcoíris Group

texts.es: En el Banco Comunal Arcoíris, ubicado en Concepción VII región de Chile, participan socios que tienen negocios como lavado de autos, ventas de queso, taller mecánico, venta de mariscos congelados, peluquería y amasandería, y nuestra entrevistada, Carolina, que está ubicada al medio de la foto de chaqueta negra y sonriendo aparece junto a un hombre de gorro amarillo; ella tiene un negocio de venta de ropa nueva, viaja a Santiago a comprar por encargo. Ella comenzó su negocio de una forma muy particular, cuando tenía 17 años su padre le regalo 500.000 mil pesos, y viajo con su hermano a Santiago a conocerlo, y compro algunas cosas en el Barrio Patronato, cuando llego a su casa vendió tanto que así empezó a ir a Santiago y comprar a pedido, a los 19 años dejo de trabajar en eso por el nacimiento de su hijo, pero el año pasado comenzó nuevamente a vender ropa. Lo malo de este negocio, nos cuenta, es cuando uno vende ropa, pero la gente no paga, ese ha sido uno de sus mayores problemas, por lo que en su regreso a la venta de ropa ha decidido solo comprar a la gente que le encarga y paga sin problemas.
